148 /**
149  Enumerate possible types of a table from re-execution
150  standpoint.
151  TABLE_LIST class has a member of this type.
152  At prepared statement prepare, this member is assigned a value
153  as of the current state of the database. Before (re-)execution
154  of a prepared statement, we check that the value recorded at
155  prepare matches the type of the object we obtained from the
156  table definition cache.
157 
158  @sa check_and_update_table_version()
159  @sa Execute_observer
160  @sa Prepared_statement::reprepare()
161 */
162

180 /**
181  Object_creation_ctx -- interface for creation context of database objects
182  (views, stored routines, events, triggers). Creation context -- is a set
183  of attributes, that should be fixed at the creation time and then be used
184  each time the object is parsed or executed.
185 */
186 
187 class Object_creation_ctx {
188  public:
189  Object_creation_ctx *set_n_backup(THD *thd);
190 
191  void restore_env(THD *thd, Object_creation_ctx *backup_ctx);
192 
193  protected:
194  Object_creation_ctx() {}
195  virtual Object_creation_ctx *create_backup_ctx(THD *thd) const = 0;
196  virtual void delete_backup_ctx() = 0;
197 
198  virtual void change_env(THD *thd) const = 0;
199 
200  public:
201  virtual ~Object_creation_ctx() {}
202 };

206 /**
207  Default_object_creation_ctx -- default implementation of
208  Object_creation_ctx.
209 */
210 
211 class Default_object_creation_ctx : public Object_creation_ctx {
212  public:
213  const CHARSET_INFO *get_client_cs() { return m_client_cs; }
214 
215  const CHARSET_INFO *get_connection_cl() { return m_connection_cl; }
216 
217  protected:
218  Default_object_creation_ctx(THD *thd);
219 
220  Default_object_creation_ctx(const CHARSET_INFO *client_cs,
221  const CHARSET_INFO *connection_cl);
222 
223  protected:
224  Object_creation_ctx *create_backup_ctx(THD *thd) const override;
225  void delete_backup_ctx() override;
226 
227  void change_env(THD *thd) const override;
228 
229  protected:
230  /**
231  client_cs stores the value of character_set_client session variable.
232  The only character set attribute is used.
233 
234  Client character set is included into query context, because we save
235  query in the original character set, which is client character set. So,
236  in order to parse the query properly we have to switch client character
237  set on parsing.
238  */
239  const CHARSET_INFO *m_client_cs;
240 
241  /**
242  connection_cl stores the value of collation_connection session
243  variable. Both character set and collation attributes are used.
244 
245  Connection collation is included into query context, becase it defines
246  the character set and collation of text literals in internal
247  representation of query (item-objects).
248  */
249  const CHARSET_INFO *m_connection_cl;
250 };

272 struct ORDER {
273  ORDER *next{nullptr};
274  /**
275  Points at the item in the select fields. Note that this means that
276  after resolving, it points into a slice (see JOIN::ref_items),
277  even though the item is not of type Item_ref!
278  */
279  Item **item{nullptr};
280  Item *item_ptr{nullptr}; /* Storage for initial item */
281  Item_rollup_group_item *rollup_item{nullptr};
282 
283  enum_order direction{
284  ORDER_NOT_RELEVANT}; /* Requested direction of ordering */
285  bool in_field_list{false}; /* true if in select field list */
286  /**
287  Tells whether this ORDER element was referenced with an alias or with an
288  expression, in the query:
289  SELECT a AS foo GROUP BY foo: true.
290  SELECT a AS foo GROUP BY a: false.
291  */
292  bool used_alias{false};
293  /**
294  When GROUP BY is implemented with a temporary table (i.e. the table takes
295  care to store only unique group rows, table->group != nullptr), each GROUP
296  BY expression is stored in a column of the table, which is
297  'field_in_tmp_table'.
298  Such field may point into table->record[0] (if we only use it to get its
299  value from a tmp table's row), or into 'buff' (if we use it to do index
300  lookup into the tmp table).
301  */
302  Field *field_in_tmp_table{nullptr};
303  char *buff{nullptr}; /* If tmp-table group */
304  table_map used{0}, depend_map{0};
305  bool is_position{false}; /* An item expresses a position in a ORDER clause */
306  bool is_explicit{false}; /* Whether ASC/DESC is explicitly specified */
307 };

309 /**
310  State information for internal tables grants.
311  This structure is part of the TABLE_LIST, and is updated
312  during the ACL check process.
313  @sa GRANT_INFO
314 */
315 struct GRANT_INTERNAL_INFO {
316  /** True if the internal lookup by schema name was done. */
317  bool m_schema_lookup_done{false};
318  /** Cached internal schema access. */
319  const ACL_internal_schema_access *m_schema_access{nullptr};
320  /** True if the internal lookup by table name was done. */
321  bool m_table_lookup_done{false};
322  /** Cached internal table access. */
323  const ACL_internal_table_access *m_table_access{nullptr};

326 /**
327  @brief The current state of the privilege checking process for the current
328  user, SQL statement and SQL object.
329 
330  @details The privilege checking process is divided into phases depending on
331  the level of the privilege to be checked and the type of object to be
332  accessed. Due to the mentioned scattering of privilege checking
333  functionality, it is necessary to keep track of the state of the process.
334 
335  A GRANT_INFO also serves as a cache of the privilege hash tables. Relevant
336  members are grant_table and version.
337  */
338 struct GRANT_INFO {
339  GRANT_INFO();
340  /**
341  @brief A copy of the privilege information regarding the current host,
342  database, object and user.
343 
344  @details The version of this copy is found in GRANT_INFO::version.
345  */
346  GRANT_TABLE *grant_table{nullptr};
347  /**
348  @brief Used for cache invalidation when caching privilege information.
349 
350  @details The privilege information is stored on disk, with dedicated
351  caches residing in memory: table-level and column-level privileges,
352  respectively, have their own dedicated caches.
353 
354  The GRANT_INFO works as a level 1 cache with this member updated to the
355  current value of the global variable @c grant_version (@c static variable
356  in sql_acl.cc). It is updated Whenever the GRANT_INFO is refreshed from
357  the level 2 cache. The level 2 cache is the @c column_priv_hash structure
358  (@c static variable in sql_acl.cc)
359 
360  @see grant_version
361  */
362  uint version{0};
363  /**
364  @brief The set of privileges that the current user has fulfilled for a
365  certain host, database, and object.
366 
367  @details This field is continually updated throughout the access checking
368  process. In each step the "wanted privilege" is checked against the
369  fulfilled privileges. When/if the intersection of these sets is empty,
370  access is granted.
371 
372  The set is implemented as a bitmap, with the bits defined in sql_acl.h.
373  */
374  ulong privilege{0};
375  /** The grant state for internal tables. */
376  GRANT_INTERNAL_INFO m_internal;
377 };
378

380  NO_TMP_TABLE,

387 /**
388  Category of table found in the table share.
389 */
390 enum enum_table_category {
391  /**
392  Unknown value.
393  */
394  TABLE_UNKNOWN_CATEGORY = 0,
395 
396  /**
397  Temporary table.
398  The table is visible only in the session.
399  Therefore,
400  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
401  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
402  do not apply to this table.
403  Note that LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
404  can be used on temporary tables.
405  Temporary tables are not part of the table cache.
406 
407  2016-06-14 Contrary to what's written in these comments, the truth is:
408  - tables created by CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE have TABLE_CATEGORY_USER
409  - tables created by create_tmp_table() (internal ones) have
410  TABLE_CATEGORY_TEMPORARY.
411  ha_innodb.cc relies on this observation (so: grep it). If you clean this
412  up, you may also want to look at 'no_tmp_table'; its enum values' meanings
413  have degraded over time: INTERNAL_TMP_TABLE is not used for some internal
414  tmp tables (derived tables). Unification of both enums would be
415  great. Whatever the result, we need to be able to distinguish the two
416  types of temporary tables above, as usage patterns are more restricted for
417  the second type, and allow more optimizations.
418  */
419  TABLE_CATEGORY_TEMPORARY = 1,
420 
421  /**
422  User table.
423  These tables do honor:
424  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
425  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
426  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
427  User tables are cached in the table cache.
428  */
429  TABLE_CATEGORY_USER = 2,
430 
431  /**
432  System table, maintained by the server.
433  These tables do honor:
434  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
435  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
436  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
437  Typically, writes to system tables are performed by
438  the server implementation, not explicitly be a user.
439  System tables are cached in the table cache.
440  */
441  TABLE_CATEGORY_SYSTEM = 3,
442 
443  /**
444  Information schema tables.
445  These tables are an interface provided by the system
446  to inspect the system metadata.
447  These tables do *not* honor:
448  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
449  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
450  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
451  as there is no point in locking explicitly
452  an INFORMATION_SCHEMA table.
453  Nothing is directly written to information schema tables.
454  Note that this value is not used currently,
455  since information schema tables are not shared,
456  but implemented as session specific temporary tables.
457  */
458  /*
459  TODO: Fixing the performance issues of I_S will lead
460  to I_S tables in the table cache, which should use
461  this table type.
462  */
463  TABLE_CATEGORY_INFORMATION = 4,
464 
465  /**
466  Log tables.
467  These tables are an interface provided by the system
468  to inspect the system logs.
469  These tables do *not* honor:
470  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
471  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
472  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
473  as there is no point in locking explicitly
474  a LOG table.
475  An example of LOG tables are:
476  - mysql.slow_log
477  - mysql.general_log,
478  which *are* updated even when there is either
479  a GLOBAL READ LOCK or a GLOBAL READ_ONLY in effect.
480  User queries do not write directly to these tables
481  (there are exceptions for log tables).
482  The server implementation perform writes.
483  Log tables are cached in the table cache.
484  */
485  TABLE_CATEGORY_LOG = 5,
486 
487  /**
488  Performance schema tables.
489  These tables are an interface provided by the system
490  to inspect the system performance data.
491  These tables do *not* honor:
492  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
493  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
494  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
495  as there is no point in locking explicitly
496  a PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA table.
497  An example of PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA tables are:
498  - performance_schema.*
499  which *are* updated (but not using the handler interface)
500  even when there is either
501  a GLOBAL READ LOCK or a GLOBAL READ_ONLY in effect.
502  User queries do not write directly to these tables
503  (there are exceptions for SETUP_* tables).
504  The server implementation perform writes.
505  Performance tables are cached in the table cache.
506  */
507  TABLE_CATEGORY_PERFORMANCE = 6,
508 
509  /**
510  Replication Information Tables.
511  These tables are used to store replication information.
512  These tables do *not* honor:
513  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
514  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
515  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
516  as there is no point in locking explicitly
517  a Replication Information table.
518  An example of replication tables are:
519  - mysql.slave_master_info
520  - mysql.slave_relay_log_info,
521  which *are* updated even when there is either
522  a GLOBAL READ LOCK or a GLOBAL READ_ONLY in effect.
523  User queries do not write directly to these tables.
524  Replication tables are cached in the table cache.
525  */
526  TABLE_CATEGORY_RPL_INFO = 7,
527 
528  /**
529  Gtid Table.
530  The table is used to store gtids.
531  The table does *not* honor:
532  - LOCK TABLE t FOR READ/WRITE
533  - FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK
534  - SET GLOBAL READ_ONLY = ON
535  as there is no point in locking explicitly
536  a Gtid table.
537  An example of gtid_executed table is:
538  - mysql.gtid_executed,
539  which is updated even when there is either
540  a GLOBAL READ LOCK or a GLOBAL READ_ONLY in effect.
541  Gtid table is cached in the table cache.
542  */
543  TABLE_CATEGORY_GTID = 8,
544 
545  /**
546  A data dictionary table.
547  Table's with this category will skip checking the
548  TABLE_SHARE versions because these table structures
549  are fixed upon server bootstrap.
550  */
551  TABLE_CATEGORY_DICTIONARY = 9,
552 
553  /**
554  A ACL metadata table.
555  For table in this category we will skip row locks when SQL statement
556  reads them.
557  */
558  TABLE_CATEGORY_ACL_TABLE = 10
559 };
560 typedef enum enum_table_category TABLE_CATEGORY;

665 /**
666  This structure is shared between different table objects. There is one
667  instance of table share per one table in the database.
668 */
669 
670 struct TABLE_SHARE {
671  TABLE_SHARE() = default;
672 
673  /**
674  Create a new TABLE_SHARE with the given version number.
675  @param version the version of the TABLE_SHARE
676  @param secondary set to true if the TABLE_SHARE represents a table
677  in a secondary storage engine
678  */
679  TABLE_SHARE(unsigned long version, bool secondary)
680  : m_version(version), m_secondary_engine(secondary) {}
681 
682  /*
683  A map of [uint, Histogram] values, where the key is the field index. The
684  map is populated with any histogram statistics when it is loaded/created.
685  */
686  malloc_unordered_map<uint, const histograms::Histogram *> *m_histograms{
687  nullptr};
688 
689  /**
690  Find the histogram for the given field index.
691 
692  @param field_index the index of the field we want to find a histogram for
693 
694  @retval nullptr if no histogram is found
695  @retval a pointer to a histogram if one is found
696  */
697  const histograms::Histogram *find_histogram(uint field_index) const;
698 
699  /** Category of this table. */
700  TABLE_CATEGORY table_category{TABLE_UNKNOWN_CATEGORY};
701 
702  /* hash of field names (contains pointers to elements of field array) */
703  collation_unordered_map<std::string, Field **> *name_hash{nullptr};
704  MEM_ROOT mem_root;

1012  /**
1013  Set share's table cache key and update its db and table name appropriately.
1014 
1015  @param key_buff Buffer with already built table cache key to be
1016  referenced from share.
1017  @param key_length Key length.
1018 
1019  @note
1020  Since 'key_buff' buffer will be referenced from share it should has same
1021  life-time as share itself.
1022  This method automatically ensures that TABLE_SHARE::table_name/db have
1023  appropriate values by using table cache key as their source.
1024  */
1025 
1026  void set_table_cache_key(char *key_buff, size_t key_length) {
1027  table_cache_key.str = key_buff;
1028  table_cache_key.length = key_length;
1029  /*
1030  Let us use the fact that the key is "db/0/table_name/0" + optional
1031  part for temporary tables.
1032  */
1033  db.str = table_cache_key.str;
1034  db.length = strlen(db.str);
1035  table_name.str = db.str + db.length + 1;
1036  table_name.length = strlen(table_name.str);
1037  }

1043  (should be at least key_length bytes).
1044  @param key Value for table cache key.
1045  @param key_length Key length.
1046 
1047  NOTE
1048  Since 'key_buff' buffer will be used as storage for table cache key
1049  it should has same life-time as share itself.
1050  */
1051 
1052  void set_table_cache_key(char *key_buff, const char *key, size_t key_length) {
1053  memcpy(key_buff, key, key_length);
1054  set_table_cache_key(key_buff, key_length);
1055  }

1070  bool has_old_version() const { return version() != refresh_version; }
1071 
1072  /**
1073  Convert unrelated members of TABLE_SHARE to one enum
1074  representing its type.
1075 
1076  @todo perhaps we need to have a member instead of a function.
1077  */
1078  enum enum_table_ref_type get_table_ref_type() const {
1079  if (is_view) return TABLE_REF_VIEW;
1080  switch (tmp_table) {
1081  case NO_TMP_TABLE:
1082  return TABLE_REF_BASE_TABLE;
1083  case SYSTEM_TMP_TABLE:
1084  return TABLE_REF_I_S_TABLE;
1085  default:
1086  return TABLE_REF_TMP_TABLE;
1087  }
1088  }
1089  /**
1090  Return a table metadata version.
1091  * for base tables and views, we return table_map_id.
1092  It is assigned from a global counter incremented for each
1093  new table loaded into the table definition cache (TDC).
1094  * for temporary tables it's table_map_id again. But for
1095  temporary tables table_map_id is assigned from
1096  thd->query_id. The latter is assigned from a thread local
1097  counter incremented for every new SQL statement. Since
1098  temporary tables are thread-local, each temporary table
1099  gets a unique id.
1100  * for everything else (e.g. information schema tables),
1101  the version id is zero.
1102 
1103  This choice of version id is a large compromise
1104  to have a working prepared statement validation in 5.1. In
1105  future version ids will be persistent, as described in WL#4180.
1106 
1107  Let's try to explain why and how this limited solution allows
1108  to validate prepared statements.
1109 
1110  Firstly, sets (in mathematical sense) of version numbers
1111  never intersect for different table types. Therefore,
1112  version id of a temporary table is never compared with
1113  a version id of a view, and vice versa.
1114 
1115  Secondly, for base tables and views, we know that each DDL flushes
1116  the respective share from the TDC. This ensures that whenever
1117  a table is altered or dropped and recreated, it gets a new
1118  version id.
1119  Unfortunately, since elements of the TDC are also flushed on
1120  LRU basis, this choice of version ids leads to false positives.
1121  E.g. when the TDC size is too small, we may have a SELECT
1122  * FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES flush all its elements, which
1123  in turn will lead to a validation error and a subsequent
1124  reprepare of all prepared statements. This is
1125  considered acceptable, since as long as prepared statements are
1126  automatically reprepared, spurious invalidation is only
1127  a performance hit. Besides, no better simple solution exists.
1128 
1129  For temporary tables, using thd->query_id ensures that if
1130  a temporary table was altered or recreated, a new version id is
1131  assigned. This suits validation needs very well and will perhaps
1132  never change.
1133 
1134  Metadata of information schema tables never changes.
1135  Thus we can safely assume 0 for a good enough version id.
1136 
1137  Finally, by taking into account table type, we always
1138  track that a change has taken place when a view is replaced
1139  with a base table, a base table is replaced with a temporary
1140  table and so on.
1141 
1142  @retval 0 For schema tables, DD tables and system views.
1143  non-0 For bases tables, views and temporary tables.
1144 
1145  @sa TABLE_LIST::is_table_ref_id_equal()
1146  */
1147  ulonglong get_table_ref_version() const;
1148 
1149  /** Determine if the table is missing a PRIMARY KEY. */
1150  bool is_missing_primary_key() const {
1151  DBUG_ASSERT(primary_key <= MAX_KEY);
1152  return primary_key == MAX_KEY;
1153  }

1189  }
1190 
1191  /**
1192  Decrement the reference count by one.
1193  @return the new reference count
1194  */
1195  unsigned int decrement_ref_count() {
1196  DBUG_ASSERT(assert_ref_count_is_locked(this));
1197  DBUG_ASSERT(!m_open_in_progress);
1198  DBUG_ASSERT(m_ref_count > 0);
1199  return --m_ref_count;
1200  }

1276 /**

1280 class Binary_diff final {

1285  size_t m_length;
1286

1288  /**
1289  Create a new Binary_diff object.

1293  */
1294  Binary_diff(size_t offset, size_t length)

1299 
1300  /// @return the length of the changed data
1301  size_t length() const { return m_length; }

1307  @return a pointer to the start of the replacement data

1317  const char *old_data(const Field *field) const;
1318 };

1320 /**

1326 using Binary_diff_vector = Mem_root_array<Binary_diff>;
1327 
1328 /**
1329  Flags for TABLE::m_status (maximum 8 bits).
1330  The flags define the state of the row buffer in TABLE::record[0].
1331 */
1332 /**
1333  STATUS_NOT_STARTED is set when table is not accessed yet.
1334  Neither STATUS_NOT_FOUND nor STATUS_NULL_ROW can be set when this flag is set.
1335 */
1336 #define STATUS_NOT_STARTED 1
1337 /**
1338  Means we were searching for a row and didn't find it. This is used by
1339  storage engines (@see handler::index_read_map()) and the executor, both
1340  when doing an exact row lookup and advancing a scan (no more rows in range).
1341 */
1342 #define STATUS_NOT_FOUND 2
1343 /// Reserved for use by multi-table update. Means the row has been updated.
1344 #define STATUS_UPDATED 16
1345 /**
1346  Means that table->null_row is set. This is an artificial NULL-filled row
1347  (one example: in outer join, if no match has been found in inner table).
1348 */
1349 #define STATUS_NULL_ROW 32
1350 /// Reserved for use by multi-table delete. Means the row has been deleted.
1351 #define STATUS_DELETED 64
1352 
1353 /* Information for one open table */
1354 enum index_hint_type { INDEX_HINT_IGNORE, INDEX_HINT_USE, INDEX_HINT_FORCE };

1799  /// Set storage handler for temporary table
1800  void set_storage_handler(handler *file_arg) {
1801  // Ensure consistent call order
1802  DBUG_ASSERT((file == nullptr && file_arg != nullptr) ||
1803  (file != nullptr && file_arg == nullptr));
1804  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_created());
1805  DBUG_ASSERT(file_arg->inited == handler::NONE);
1806  file = file_arg;
1807  }

1813  that could not be enabled without an instantiated table.
1814  */
1815  void set_created();
1816  /**
1817  Set the contents of table to be "deleted", ie "not created", after having
1818  deleted the contents.
1819  */
1820  void set_deleted() { created = materialized = false; }
1821  /// Set table as nullable, ie it is inner wrt some outer join
1822  void set_nullable() { nullable = true; }

1825  bool is_nullable() const { return nullable; }
1826 
1827  /// @return true if table contains one or more generated columns
1828  bool has_gcol() const { return vfield; }
1829 
1830  /**
1831  Life cycle of the row buffer is as follows:
1832  - The initial state is "not started".
1833  - When reading a row through the storage engine handler, the status is set
1834  as "has row" or "no row", depending on whether a row was found or not.
1835  The "not started" state is cleared, as well as the "null row" state,
1836  the updated state and the deleted state.
1837  - When making a row available in record[0], make sure to update row status
1838  similarly to how the storage engine handler does it.
1839  - If a NULL-extended row is needed in join execution, the "null row" state
1840  is set. Note that this can be combined with "has row" if a row was read
1841  but condition on it was evaluated to false (happens for single-row
1842  lookup), or "no row" if no more rows could be read.
1843  Note also that for the "null row" state, the NULL bits inside the
1844  row are set to one, so the row inside the row buffer is no longer usable,
1845  unless the NULL bits are saved in a separate buffer.
1846  - The "is updated" and "is deleted" states are set when row is updated or
1847  deleted, respectively.
1848  */
1849  /// Set status for row buffer as "not started"
1850  void set_not_started() {
1851  m_status = STATUS_NOT_STARTED | STATUS_NOT_FOUND;
1852  null_row = false;
1853  }
1854 
1855  /// @return true if a row operation has been done
1856  bool is_started() const { return !(m_status & STATUS_NOT_STARTED); }
1857 
1858  /// Set status for row buffer: contains row
1859  void set_found_row() {
1860  m_status = 0;
1861  null_row = false;
1862  }
1863 
1864  /**
1865  Set status for row buffer: contains no row. This is set when
1866  - A lookup operation finds no row
1867  - A scan operation scans past the last row of the range.
1868  - An error in generating key values before calling storage engine.
1869  */
1870  void set_no_row() {
1871  m_status = STATUS_NOT_FOUND;
1872  null_row = false;
1873  }
1874 
1875  /**
1876  Set "row found" status from handler result
1877 
1878  @param status 0 if row was found, <> 0 if row was not found
1879  */
1880  void set_row_status_from_handler(int status) {
1881  m_status = status ? STATUS_NOT_FOUND : 0;
1882  null_row = false;
1883  }
1884 
1885  /**
1886  Set current row as "null row", for use in null-complemented outer join.
1887  The row buffer may or may not contain a valid row.
1888  set_null_row() and reset_null_row() are used by the join executor to
1889  signal the presence or absence of a NULL-extended row for an outer joined
1890  table. Null rows may also be used to specify rows that are all NULL in
1891  grouing operations.
1892  @note this is a destructive operation since the NULL value bit vector
1893  is overwritten. Caching operations must be aware of this.
1894  */
1895  void set_null_row() {
1896  null_row = true;
1897  m_status |= STATUS_NULL_ROW;
1898  if (s->null_bytes > 0) memset(null_flags, 255, s->null_bytes);
1899  }
1900 
1901  /// Clear "null row" status for the current row
1902  void reset_null_row() {
1903  null_row = false;
1904  m_status &= ~STATUS_NULL_ROW;
1905  }
1906 
1907  /// Set "updated" property for the current row
1908  void set_updated_row() {
1909  DBUG_ASSERT(is_started() && has_row());
1910  m_status |= STATUS_UPDATED;
1911  }
1912 
1913  /// Set "deleted" property for the current row
1914  void set_deleted_row() {
1915  DBUG_ASSERT(is_started() && has_row());
1916  m_status |= STATUS_DELETED;
1917  }
1918 
1919  /// @return true if there is a row in row buffer
1920  bool has_row() const { return !(m_status & STATUS_NOT_FOUND); }
1921 
1922  /// @return true if current row is null-extended
1923  bool has_null_row() const { return null_row; }
1924 
1925  /// @return true if current row has been updated (multi-table update)
1926  bool has_updated_row() const { return m_status & STATUS_UPDATED; }
1927 
1928  /// @return true if current row has been deleted (multi-table delete)
1929  bool has_deleted_row() const { return m_status & STATUS_DELETED; }
1930 
1931  /// Save the NULL flags of the current row into the designated buffer
1932  void save_null_flags() {
1933  if (s->null_bytes > 0) memcpy(null_flags_saved, null_flags, s->null_bytes);
1934  }
1935 
1936  /// Restore the NULL flags of the current row from the designated buffer
1937  void restore_null_flags() {
1938  if (s->null_bytes > 0) memcpy(null_flags, null_flags_saved, s->null_bytes);
1939  }

1942  bool empty_result_table();

2505 class Table_function;
2506 /*
2507  Table reference in the FROM clause.
2508 
2509  These table references can be of several types that correspond to
2510  different SQL elements. Below we list all types of TABLE_LISTs with
2511  the necessary conditions to determine when a TABLE_LIST instance
2512  belongs to a certain type.
2513 
2514  1) table (TABLE_LIST::view == NULL)
2515  - base table
2516  (TABLE_LIST::derived == NULL)
2517  - subquery - TABLE_LIST::table is a temp table
2518  (TABLE_LIST::derived != NULL)
2519  - information schema table
2520  (TABLE_LIST::schema_table != NULL)
2521  NOTICE: for schema tables TABLE_LIST::field_translation may be != NULL
2522  2) view (TABLE_LIST::view != NULL)
2523  - merge (TABLE_LIST::effective_algorithm == VIEW_ALGORITHM_MERGE)
2524  also (TABLE_LIST::field_translation != NULL)
2525  - temptable(TABLE_LIST::effective_algorithm == VIEW_ALGORITHM_TEMPTABLE)
2526  also (TABLE_LIST::field_translation == NULL)
2527  3) nested table reference (TABLE_LIST::nested_join != NULL)
2528  - table sequence - e.g. (t1, t2, t3)
2529  TODO: how to distinguish from a JOIN?
2530  - general JOIN
2531  TODO: how to distinguish from a table sequence?
2532  - NATURAL JOIN
2533  (TABLE_LIST::natural_join != NULL)
2534  - JOIN ... USING
2535  (TABLE_LIST::join_using_fields != NULL)
2536  - semi-join
2537  ;
2538 */
2539 
2540 struct TABLE_LIST {
2541  TABLE_LIST() = default;
2542 
2543  /**
2544  Only to be used by legacy code that temporarily needs a TABLE_LIST, more
2545  specifically: Query_result_create::binlog_show_create_table().
2546  */
2547  explicit TABLE_LIST(TABLE *table_arg) : table(table_arg) {}
2548 
2549  /// Constructor that can be used when the strings are null terminated.
2550  TABLE_LIST(const char *db_name, const char *table_name,
2551  enum thr_lock_type lock_type)
2552  : TABLE_LIST(db_name, strlen(db_name), table_name, strlen(table_name),
2553  table_name, lock_type) {}
2554 
2555  /**
2556  Creates a TABLE_LIST object with pre-allocated strings for database, table
2557  and alias.
2558  */

2712  void set_join_cond(Item *val) {
2713  // If optimization has started, it's too late to change m_join_cond.
2714  DBUG_ASSERT(m_join_cond_optim == nullptr || m_join_cond_optim == (Item *)1);
2715  m_join_cond = val;
2716  }
2717  Item *join_cond_optim() const { return m_join_cond_optim; }
2718  void set_join_cond_optim(Item *cond) {
2719  /*
2720  Either we are setting to "empty", or there must pre-exist a
2721  permanent condition.
2722  */
2723  DBUG_ASSERT(cond == nullptr || cond == (Item *)1 || m_join_cond != nullptr);
2724  m_join_cond_optim = cond;
2725  }
2726  Item **join_cond_optim_ref() { return &m_join_cond_optim; }

2763  Retrieve the last (right-most) leaf in a nested join tree with
2764  respect to name resolution.
2765 
2766 
2767  Given that 'this' is a nested table reference, recursively walk
2768  down the right-most children of 'this' until we reach a leaf
2769  table reference with respect to name resolution.
2770 
2771  The right-most child of a nested table reference is the first
2772  element in the list of children because the children are inserted
2773  in reverse order.

2946  /**
2947  Return true if this is a view or derived table that is defined over
2948  more than one base table, and false otherwise.
2949  */
2950  bool is_multiple_tables() const {
2951  if (is_view_or_derived()) {
2952  DBUG_ASSERT(is_merged()); // Cannot be a materialized view
2953  return leaf_tables_count() > 1;
2954  } else {
2955  DBUG_ASSERT(nested_join == nullptr); // Must be a base table
2956  return false;
2957  }
2958  }

2963  /// Return first leaf table of a base table or a view/derived table
2964  TABLE_LIST *first_leaf_table() {
2965  TABLE_LIST *tr = this;
2966  while (tr->merge_underlying_list) tr = tr->merge_underlying_list;
2967  return tr;
2968  }
2969 
2970  /// Return any leaf table that is not an inner table of an outer join
2971  /// @todo WL#6570 with prepare-once, replace with first_leaf_table()
2972  /// when WL#6059 is merged in (it really converts RIGHT JOIN to
2973  /// LEFT JOIN so the first leaf is part of a LEFT JOIN,
2974  /// guaranteed).
2975  TABLE_LIST *any_outer_leaf_table() {
2976  TABLE_LIST *tr = this;
2977  while (tr->merge_underlying_list) {
2978  tr = tr->merge_underlying_list;
2979  /*
2980  "while" is used, however, an "if" might be sufficient since there is
2981  no more than one inner table in a join nest (with outer_join true).
2982  */
2983  while (tr->outer_join) tr = tr->next_local;
2984  }
2985  return tr;
2986  }

3117  /**
3118  @brief Returns the outer join nest that this TABLE_LIST belongs to, if any.
3119 
3120  @details There are two kinds of join nests, outer-join nests and semi-join
3121  nests. This function returns non-NULL in the following cases:
3122  @li 1. If this table/nest is embedded in a nest and this nest IS NOT a
3123  semi-join nest. (In other words, it is an outer-join nest.)
3124  @li 2. If this table/nest is embedded in a nest and this nest IS a
3125  semi-join nest, but this semi-join nest is embedded in another
3126  nest. (This other nest will be an outer-join nest, since all inner
3127  joined nested semi-join nests have been merged in
3128  @c simplify_joins() ).
3129  Note: This function assumes that @c simplify_joins() has been performed.
3130  Before that, join nests will be present for all types of join.
3131 
3132  @return outer join nest, or NULL if none.
3133  */
3134 
3135  TABLE_LIST *outer_join_nest() const {
3136  if (!embedding) return nullptr;
3137  if (embedding->is_sj_nest()) return embedding->embedding;
3138  return embedding;
3139  }
3140  /**
3141  Return true if this table is an inner table of some outer join.
3142 
3143  Examine all the embedding join nests of the table.
3144  @note This function works also before redundant join nests have been
3145  eliminated.
3146 
3147  @return true if table is an inner table of some outer join, false otherwise.
3148  */
3149 
3150  bool is_inner_table_of_outer_join() const {
3151  if (outer_join) return true;
3152  for (TABLE_LIST *emb = embedding; emb; emb = emb->embedding) {
3153  if (emb->outer_join) return true;
3154  }
3155  return false;
3156  }
3157 
3158  /**
3159  Return the base table entry of an updatable table.
3160  In DELETE and UPDATE, a view used as a target table must be mergeable,
3161  updatable and defined over a single table.
3162  */
3163  const TABLE_LIST *updatable_base_table() const {
3164  const TABLE_LIST *tbl = this;
3165  DBUG_ASSERT(tbl->is_updatable() && !tbl->is_multiple_tables());
3166  while (tbl->is_view_or_derived()) {
3167  tbl = tbl->merge_underlying_list;
3168  DBUG_ASSERT(tbl->is_updatable() && !tbl->is_multiple_tables());
3169  }
3170  return tbl;
3171  }
3172 
3173  TABLE_LIST *updatable_base_table() {
3174  return const_cast<TABLE_LIST *>(
3175  static_cast<const TABLE_LIST *>(this)->updatable_base_table());
3176  }
3177 
3178  /**
3179  Mark that there is a NATURAL JOIN or JOIN ... USING between two tables.
3180 
3181  This function marks that table b should be joined with a either via
3182  a NATURAL JOIN or via JOIN ... USING. Both join types are special
3183  cases of each other, so we treat them together. The function
3184  setup_conds() creates a list of equal condition between all fields
3185  of the same name for NATURAL JOIN or the fields in
3186  TABLE_LIST::join_using_fields for JOIN ... USING.
3187  The list of equality conditions is stored
3188  either in b->join_cond(), or in JOIN::conds, depending on whether there
3189  was an outer join.
3190 
3191  EXAMPLE
3192  @verbatim
3193  SELECT * FROM t1 NATURAL LEFT JOIN t2
3194  <=>
3195  SELECT * FROM t1 LEFT JOIN t2 ON (t1.i=t2.i and t1.j=t2.j ... )
3196 
3197  SELECT * FROM t1 NATURAL JOIN t2 WHERE <some_cond>
3198  <=>
3199  SELECT * FROM t1, t2 WHERE (t1.i=t2.i and t1.j=t2.j and <some_cond>)
3200 
3201  SELECT * FROM t1 JOIN t2 USING(j) WHERE <some_cond>
3202  <=>
3203  SELECT * FROM t1, t2 WHERE (t1.j=t2.j and <some_cond>)
3204  @endverbatim
3205 
3206  @param b Right join argument.
3207  */
3208  void add_join_natural(TABLE_LIST *b) { b->natural_join = this; }
3209

3212

3214  resolver process, such as when generating a UNION table
3215 
3216  @param privilege Privileges granted for this table.
3217  */
3218  void set_privileges(ulong privilege) { grant.privilege |= privilege; }

3714  public:
3715  Field_iterator_table() : ptr(nullptr) {}
3716  void set(TABLE_LIST *table) override { ptr = table->table->field; }
3717  void set_table(TABLE *table) { ptr = table->field; }
3718  void next() override { ptr++; }
3719  bool end_of_fields() override { return *ptr == nullptr; }
3720  const char *name() override;

3722  Field *field() override { return *ptr; }

4035 /**
4036  Check if a TABLE_LIST instance represents a pre-opened temporary table.
4037 */
4038 
4039 inline bool is_temporary_table(const TABLE_LIST *tl) {
4040  if (tl->is_view() || tl->schema_table) return false;
4041 
4042  if (!tl->table) return false;
4043 
4044  /*
4045  NOTE: 'table->s' might be NULL for specially constructed TABLE
4046  instances. See SHOW TRIGGERS for example.
4047  */
4048 
4049  if (!tl->table->s) return false;
4050 
4051  return tl->table->s->tmp_table != NO_TMP_TABLE;
4052 }

4054 /**
4055  After parsing, a Common Table Expression is accessed through a

4057  TABLE_LIST needs.

4067  bool substitute_recursive_reference(THD *thd, SELECT_LEX *sl);
4068  /// Empties the materialized CTE and informs all of its clones.
4069  bool clear_all_references();

4071  All references to this CTE in the statement, except those inside the
4072  query expression defining this CTE.
4073  In other words, all non-recursive references.

4075  Mem_root_array<TABLE_LIST *> references;

4081  has a TABLE generated by create_tmp_table(); other ones have a TABLE
4082  generated by open_table_from_share().
4083  */
4084  Mem_root_array<TABLE_LIST *> tmp_tables;

4089 /**
4090  This iterates on those references to a derived table / view / CTE which are
4091  materialized. If a recursive CTE, this includes recursive references.
4092  Upon construction it is passed a non-recursive materialized reference
4093  to the derived table (TABLE_LIST*).
4094  For a CTE it may return more than one reference; for a derived table or a
4095  view, there is only one (as references to a same view are treated as
4096  independent objects).
4097  References are returned as TABLE*.
4098 */
4099 class Derived_refs_iterator {
4100  TABLE_LIST *const start; ///< The reference provided in construction.
4101  int ref_idx; ///< Current index in cte->tmp_tables
4102  public:
4103  explicit Derived_refs_iterator(TABLE_LIST *start_arg)
4104  : start(start_arg), ref_idx(-1) {}
4105  TABLE *get_next() {
4106  ref_idx++;
4107  const Common_table_expr *cte = start->common_table_expr();
4108  if (!cte) return (ref_idx < 1) ? start->table : nullptr;
4109  return ((uint)ref_idx < cte->tmp_tables.size())
4110  ? cte->tmp_tables[ref_idx]->table
4111  : nullptr;
4112  }
4113  void rewind() { ref_idx = -1; }
4114  /// @returns true if the last get_next() returned the first element.
4115  bool is_first() const { return ref_idx == 0; }
4116 };

4133 
4134 // Whether we can ask the storage engine for the row ID of the last row read.
4135 //
4136 // Some operations needs a row ID to operate correctly (i.e. weedout). Normally,
4137 // the row ID is provided by the storage engine by calling handler::position().
4138 // But there are cases when position() should not be called:
4139 //
4140 // 1. If we have a const table (rows are fetched during optimization), we
4141 // should not call position().
4142 // 2. If we have a NULL-complemented row, calling position() would give a
4143 // random row ID back, as there has not been any row read.
4144 //
4145 // Operations that needs the row ID must also check the value of
4146 // QEP_TAB::rowid_status to see whether they actually need a row ID.
4147 // See QEP_TAB::rowid_status for more details.
4148 inline bool can_call_position(const TABLE *table) {
4149  return !table->const_table && !(table->is_nullable() && table->null_row);
4150 }
